Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Chlorine Activation in Biomass Burning Plumes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaborative effort to investigate the emissions of particulate chloride from biomass burning and the implications of these emissions on the formation of atmospheric ozone and small particles. The effort combines the facilities and expertise of atmospheric chemists at Carnegie-Mellon University (CMU) and University of Washington (UW) for the purpose of conducting a detailed set of laboratory experiments in a large smog chamber reactor in CMU's combustion facility. The chamber will be filled with smoke from the open combustion of globally relevant chloride emitting biomass fuels such as various types of grasses (e.g. Sawgrass, Wiregrass, Rice straw), and Palmetto (small palm species). Changes in the concentrations of gas-phase reactants and products will be determined in real-time using UW's state-of-the-art chemical measurement instrumentation. The investigators will apply kinetic box models to derive the combination of parameters that give the best measurement-model agreement for the development of parameters that can be used in regional and global models.

Particulate chloride undergoes efficient reactions with nitrogen oxide gases, releasing nitryl chloride (ClNO2) in the gas phase. The presence of ClNO2 can significantly perturb the troposphere's oxidant budget, the cycling of chlorine (ClOx), hydrogen (HOx), and NOx radicals, the oxidation of organic compounds and associated organic aerosol formation, and ground-level ozone levels. This project will be the first laboratory study to investigate the formation and yield of ClNO2 from dinitrogen pentoxide (N2O5), reacting with chloride in particle systems representative of biomass burning aerosols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biomass burning is the combustion of wood and other plant matter during wildfires and prescribed burns. Wildfires are increasing in frequency and intensity due to climate change-driven drought, and are a major and growing source of pollutant emissions to the atmosphere. While the major components emitted in biomass-burning smoke aerosol are organic carbon and black carbon soot, we investigated the emissions and chemical behavior of two understudied components of wildfire smoke aerosol: chloride salt phases, and mineral particles. Both of these components are enriched in the emissions from the combustion of tall grass species, as opposed to from wood.

We hypothesized that the chloride salts often emitted in biomass-burning aerosol are prone to reaction with trace oxidant gases, similar to how the chloride in sea spray aerosol undergoes chemical reactions with gas-phase reactants. These gas-particle reactions can produce important new reactants such as nitryl chloride (ClNO2(g)) through reactive uptake of dinitrogen pentoxide (N2O5(g)). N2O5 is a key nighttime reservoir of nitrogen oxides, which are important precursors for photochemical smog and ozone production. The main loss pathway for N2O5(g) is conversion to nitric acid (HNO3) through hydrolysis with aqueous aerosol. Particulate chloride presents another chemical pathway for N2O5 hydrolysis through the production of ClNO2(g). Which reaction pathway N2O5(g) takes is important as HNO3 is a sink for nitrogen oxides, but ClNO2 recycles nitrogen oxides when it photolyzes and also liberates a potent chlorine radical oxidant. This multiphase chemistry had never been directly explored in biomass-burning aerosol, though there were indications from atmospheric field measurements that chloride is displaced through atmospheric chemical aging during transport.

We performed the first smog chamber reactor experiments on authentic biomass-burning emissions under dark nocturnal conditions to test our hypothesis that N2O5(g) is produced in these emissions and can react with chloride salts, producing ClNO2(g). A chemical ionization mass spectrometer using iodide-attachment ionization was used to measure N2O5(g), ClNO2(g), and other gas-phase vapors. A soot-particle aerosol mass spectrometer measured changes in the chemical composition of the particle phase. In all the authentic biomass fuels tested, including softwood, hardwood, and tall grass species, N2O5(g) formed following the addition of ozone gas. In each experiment ClNO2(g) was then observed to form, and the maximum amount of ClNO2(g) produced was correlated with the chloride mass fraction of the aerosol, and the maximum amount of N2O5(g) produced. This supported our two hypotheses regarding the production of N2O5(g) and ClNO2(g) under nocturnal conditions in biomass-burning smoke. This has important implications for the cycling of radical oxidants and nitrogen oxides that are key components of photochemical smog, air toxics, and ozone precursors. The reactions observed here may explain the high concentrations of ClNO2(g) often observed inland far from marine sources of chloride.

To determine the kinetics or rate of reaction of N2O5(g) with biomass-burning aerosol we performed kinetics experiments in an entrained aerosol flow tube reactor where the relative humidity and concentration of N2O5(g) can be precisely controlled. These experiments determine the reaction probability of N2O5(g), or number of gas-particle collisions that lead to successful chemical reaction. Four biomass fuels of varying chloride content were examined and the N2O5 reaction probability was found to be consistently low in all cases. This is surprising given the large amounts of chloride present in some of the fuels. Only one tall grass fuel was found to produce substantial ClNO2(g), and this is likely due to the only minutes of reaction time in the flow tube compared to more than an hour in the chamber reactor. We hypothesized that the slow reaction kinetics of N2O5 was due to the morphology and availability of the chloride salt phases, or due to the aerosol not experiencing high enough relative humidity for the salts to deliquesce into a more reactive aqueous phase. Additional experiments at elevated RH > 80% increased the N2O5 reaction probability by up to a factor of 10, confirming that deliquescence limitations are important. Electron microscopy imaging of collected aerosol particles found that organic carbon coatings often concealed the salt phases and that these coatings were thicker and more stable as RH was increased for some fuels. Therefore both deliquescence limitations and the morphology, mixing state, and presence of organic carbon coatings can significantly alter the availability of chloride to undergo reaction with gases such as N2O5(g). This research has generated key experimental data that can be used to accurately represent this significant and complex chemistry in atmospheric chemistry models. This will enable a more complete understanding of the numerous impacts that wildfires impart on the Earth and climate systems, as wildfires continue to become more prevalent.
